abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Emergency Drought
            Recovery Project for Kenya was satisfactory. The project
            partly achieved all of its objectives, its impact on
            institutional development was substantial, sustainability is
            likely, and the performance of both the Bank and Borrower
            was satisfactory. Several lessons can be learned from this
            project. First, emergency projects need to be formulated so
            that they meet priority needs and, as with non-emergency
            projects, local consultation and assessment is a necessary
            part of the design process. Second, there is justification
            for distributing free seed to impoverished farmers to assist
            in their drought recovery. Third, rapid disbursement is
            essential for emergency projects and standard Bank and
            Government procedures can cause delays in delivery. Fourth,
            the time scale required for road improvements means that
            this type of activity can rarely be accommodated in a
            two-year project. Fifth, mismanagement of funds, when
            detected, needs to be dealt with swiftly and decisively.
            Finally, drought relief in pastoral areas is likely to
            require support for societal restocking, resource sharing,
            and keeping selected animals alive for rebuilding herds later.

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Emergency Drought
            Recovery Project is to fund specific components of the
            government's overall drought recovery program (DRP) to
            assist the arid and semi-arid lands (ASAL) populations
            affected by the drought to begin a sustainable recovery
            process.  The project consists of several components: (a)
            agricultural inputs, including supply of packages of seed
            and fertilizer, and a limited number of hand tools, for free
            distribution to farmers in the ASAL district; (b) livestock
            component including provision of vaccines, trypanocidal
            drugs, clinical drugs, vaccination equipment and other
            consumable and operating costs associated with carrying out
            vaccination and animal treatment programs; (c) drought
            management including operating costs, training, short-term
            technical assistance, vehicles and office equipment; (d)
            environmental component which provides operating costs,
            materials and supplies, and training and short-term
            technical assistance to test different approaches to
            resource base preservation; (e) infrastructure including
            rehabilitation of about 420 km of critical roads and
            technical assistance; (f) water component including
            rehabilitation of existing water facilities, capacity
            building, and provision of three water tankers to meet
            temporary water transportation needs; (g) health component
            which provides drugs and medical supplies, rehabilitation of
            buildings, operating costs, and training; and (h)
            implementation to establish a project management unit.
